title: 894: In Case You Missed It in May 2025 â€” with Jon Krohn (@JonKrohnLearns)

rawLines.text: This is episode number 894, our in case
you missed it in May
episode. Welcome back to the Super Data
Science podcast. I am your host, John
Cone. This is an in case you missed it
episode that highlights the best parts
of conversations we had on the show over
the past month. In the first of my four
highlights from May, I speak to John
Rose, global CTO and chief AI officer at
the computing giant Dell. What a guest.
Uh John and I had a detailed
conversation about multi-agent teams,
quantum computing, and the future of
work in episode 887. And in this clip, I
asked him to define two terms, AI agent
and ragbased chatbot. Let's talk about
the natural next step that has emerged
after generative AI which is agentic
systems because as generative AI has
become powerful enough as LLM have
become reliable enough we've started to
be able to rely on them more and more on
their own. Do you have John your own
definition of what an agent is? Yeah,
I'm going to give you a a bigger picture
view and then I'll define an agent. So
um
AI attached to the enterprise applying
AI to the enterprise actually has two
different parts to it of which only one
we've done so far. Agents are the second
one. And the reason for that is the
source of differentiation of an
enterprise. And a lot of us in the
industry have said this over the last
couple of years and even though people
weren't necessarily paying attention but
there were two parts that make an
enterprise an enterprise. The real core
source of differentiation. The first is
your proprietary data. you know, things
other people don't know. That's actually
very powerful. That's why you don't
share your proprietary data with people.
You know, my customer list is very
valuable. My source code is very
valuable. And and those are a a
sustainable source of differentiation.
Even if the people change, the brand
changes, the world changes, having
proprietary data is very very important.
The second source of differentiation is
the unique skills in your organization
that you have people that can do things
better than other people. At Dell, we
have the best thermal and cooling people
in the world, the best client developers
in the world, the best storage software
developers in the world. And the result
of that is that translates into better
products in interesting innovation
patents. And so if those are the two
sources of differentiation and the
journey we're on is to apply AI to an
enterprise and those are the two things
that matter. It's interesting because
for the first couple years of Gen AI, we
actually went after the first one. a
chatbot, a rag system, all of these
things are just tools that allow us to
unlock and and create value from our
proprietary data. What is a ragbased
chatbot? It is a tool that takes
proprietary data and makes it
generative. It makes you you could take
all of your service information and if
you if I gave it all to you in raw
format, it would be of no value. If I
embed it into a vector database and
present it to you through a generative
interface, you can ask and answer any
question on anything I know anywhere.
That is incredibly powerful and we have
been doing that now for about a year at
scale in the industry and it's
transforming everything. We're getting
huge value out of this. In fact, almost
all of our our projects that are in
production are just that they're a
generative capability to unlock our
proprietary data in novel ways that just
changes the curve in terms of
productivity. That's great. Agents are
not that. Agents go after the second
one. They are about the digitization of
a skill. They are about saying, "I'm not
just interested in unlocking the data.
I'm interested in distributing the work.
I actually want an AI that doesn't even
require me to do a task. That it can
actually operate autonomously. It can
operate without human intervention. In
fact, I'm not even going to tell it how
to do the job. I'm just going to give it
an objective and let it go." And I'm
doing this aligned to the skills that I
need it to do. So for instance, you
know, when we think about agents in the
enterprise, now there's there's two
views of this in the current thinking.
One one thinking out there is that
agents will be replacements for
multi-dimensional humans that can do
everything. That's AGI and ASI. We're a
long ways away from that. Um the reality
of agents is that they are actually the
digitization of more narrow skills. It's
what I use the self-driving car example.
I do not have a self-driving car today
that can drive anywhere in any situation
and navigate it successfully. What we do
have is self-driving cars. They've been
in San Francisco and other places where
if you geoence it, if you narrow the
scope, we see this in the trains and
airports, there's no driver on them
because it has one job. It does it moves
from terminal to terminal without a
human intervention. Well, that's what's
going on with agents. The first
generation of agents are saying, could I
take a task, a skill, and could I move
it into AI, not as a tool that a person
uses, but as a manifestation of that
skill autonomously that I can just tell
it to do something. I can give it an
objective and it's smart enough to
figure out how to reason through that
objective. It has access to a set of
data and it can deliver an outcome
equivalent or better than what a human
would have done for that particular
skill, you know, and and yeah, there
might actually be humans doing those
specific jobs that might not do them
anymore because agents can absorb them.
But what you don't have is a fully
well-rounded entity that is the
equivalent of a full human being that
can do lots of different things. Like
think about in your life, how many
different things can you do? Well, today
the manifestation of agents can probably
pick off a few of those, but what they
can't do is pick off all of them and
create a
completely, you know, equivalent of your
whole well-rounded human being,
including your ethics, your morality.
That's a really hard problem. That's AGI
and ASI. We different journey. And so so
bottom line is you take these two
technologies first gen AI which is what
we call reactive AI that a human is in
the loop and the human asks the AI to do
something and it gives it an immediate
response but ultimately the human is the
doer of the work and these are tools
around the human and then you move over
to this kind of second generation of
agentic AI which are complimentary and
now you have a situation where the human
is on the loop they are the supervisor
and all they are doing is creating
objectives and delegating work and now
the AI independently is able to take
that task figure it out, run with it,
and even run with it in perpetuity that
it may never go back to the human being
because it's been delegated below the
machine line. These are the reason it's
so important to distinguish these is
one, they aren't even the same
technology. While this one, the center
of the universe is a large language
model with some data around it. It's
very static data set. An agentic
environment has large language models,
but they're used for part of the
equation. They act they act as somewhat
of its brain, but it has a body. It has
a knowledge graph where it creates its
own representation of data that it
represents what it's learned and its
memories and its its evolution of
skills. It has interfaces around it that
allow it to reach out into the real
world. Something called tool use that
and function serving where it can
actually go and activate a tool and
interact with the world and perceive
things. Very different technical
architecture and quite frankly
appropriately so because it's solving a
different problem. Now you fast forward
into the future of an enterprise. Well,
yep. still got proprietary data and
still got unique skills except now I
have a path to digitize both of them and
that's the thing that's going to
profoundly change most enterprises. John
touches on an important point about the
future of AI being in the
interconnectivity between tools such as
AI agents and ragbased chat bots and I
recommend listening to the entire
episode to hear more about how John's
team applies such integrations at Dell
based on the social media response.
Listeners absolutely loved that episode.

cleanText:
This is Episode 894, our "in case you missed it" May episode. Welcome back to the SuperDataScience Podcast. I am your host, Jon Krohn. This is an "in case you missed it" episode that highlights the best parts of conversations we had on the show over the past month. In the first of my four highlights from May, I speak to John Roese, Global CTO and Chief AI Officer at Dell Technologies. What a guest! John and I had a detailed conversation about multi-agent teams, quantum computing, and the future of work in Episode 887. And in this clip, I asked him to define two terms: AI agent integration and RAG-based chatbots. Let's talk about the natural next step that has emerged after generative AI, which is agentic systems. Because as generative AI has become powerful enough, as LLMs have become reliable enough, we've started to be able to rely on them more and more on their own. Do you have, John, your own definition of what an agent is?

Yeah, I'm going to give you a bigger picture view and then I'll define an agent. So, AI attached to the enterprise, applying AI to the enterprise, actually has two different parts to it, of which only one we've done so far. Agents are the second one. And the reason for that is the source of differentiation of an enterprise. And a lot of us in the industry have said this over the last couple of years, and even though people weren't necessarily paying attention, but there were two parts that make an enterprise an enterprise: the real core source of differentiation. The first is your proprietary data; you know, things other people don't know. That's actually very powerful. That's why you don't share your proprietary data with people. You know, my customer list is very valuable. My source code is very valuable. And those are a sustainable source of differentiation. Even if the people change, the brand changes, the world changes, having proprietary data is very, very important.

The second source of differentiation is the unique skills in your organization; that you have people that can do things better than other people. At Dell Technologies, we have the best thermal and cooling people in the world, the best client developers in the world, the best storage software developers in the world. And the result of that is that translates into better products and interesting innovation patents. And so if those are the two sources of differentiation and the journey we're on is to apply AI to an enterprise, and those are the two things that matter. It's interesting because for the first couple of years of Gen AI, we actually went after the first one: a chatbot, a RAG systemâ€”all of these things are just tools that allow us to unlock and create value from our proprietary data. What is a RAG-based chatbot? It is a tool that takes proprietary data and makes it generative. It makesâ€”you could take all of your service information, and if youâ€”if I gave it all to you in raw format, it would be of no value. If I embed it into a vector database and present it to you through a generative interface, you can ask and answer any question on anything I know anywhere. That is incredibly powerful, and we have been doing that now for about a year at scale in the industry, and it's transforming everything. We're getting huge value out of this. In fact, almost all of our projects that are in production are just that: they're a generative capability to unlock our proprietary data in novel ways that just changes the curve in terms of productivity.

That's great. Agents are not that. Agents go after the second one. They are about the digitization of a skill. They are about saying, "I'm not just interested in unlocking the data. I'm interested in distributing the work. I actually want an AI that doesn't even require me to do a task; that it can actually operate autonomously. It can operate without human intervention. In fact, I'm not even going to tell it how to do the job. I'm just going to give it an objective and let it go." And I'm doing this aligned to the skills that I need it to do. So, for instance, you know, when we think about agents in the enterprise, now there'sâ€”there's two views of this in the current thinking. One thinking out there is that agents will be replacements for multi-dimensional humans that can do everything. That's AGI and ASI. We're a long ways away from that. The reality of agents is that they are actually the digitization of more narrow skills. It's what I use the self-driving car example. I do not have a self-driving car today that can drive anywhere in any situation and navigate it successfully. What we do have is self-driving cars. They've been in San Francisco and other places where, if you geo-fence it, if you narrow the scopeâ€”we see this in the trains and airports; there's no driver on them because it has one job. It doesâ€”it moves from terminal to terminal without human intervention. Well, that's what's going on with agents. The first generation of agents are saying, "Could I take a task, a skill, and could I move it into AI, not as a tool that a person uses, but as a manifestation of that skill autonomously that I can just tell it to do something? I can give it an objective, and it's smart enough to figure out how to reason through that objective. It has access to a set of data, and it can deliver an outcome equivalent or better than what a human would have done for that particular skill," you know, andâ€”and yeah, there might actually be humans doing those specific jobs that might not do them anymore because agents can absorb them. But what you don't have is a fully well-rounded entity that is the equivalent of a full human being that can do lots of different things. Like think about in your life, how many different things can you do? Well, today the manifestation of agents can probably pick off a few of those, but what they can't do is pick off all of them and create a completely, you know, equivalent of your whole well-rounded human being, including your ethics, your morality. That's a really hard problem. That's AGI and ASI. We're on a different journey. And so, the bottom line is you take these two technologies: first-gen AI, which is what we call reactive AI, that a human is in the loop, and the humanâ€¦


Asks the AI to do something, and it gives an immediate response; but ultimately, the human is the doer of the work, and these are tools around the human. Then you move over to this kind of second generation of agentic AI, which are complimentary. Now you have a situation where the human is on the loop; they are the supervisor, and all they are doing is creating objectives and delegating work. Now the AI independently is able to take that task, figure it out, run with it, and even run with it in perpetuityâ€”that it may never go back to the human being because it's been delegated below the machine line.  These are the reasons it's so important to distinguish these: one, they aren't even the same technology. While this one, the center of the universe is a large language model with some data around itâ€”it's a very static data set. An agentic environment has large language models, but they're used for part of the equation. They act as somewhat of its brain, but it has a body. It has a knowledge graph where it creates its own representation of data that represents what it's learned, its memories, and its evolution of skills. It has interfaces around it that allow it to reach out into the real worldâ€”something called tool use and function servingâ€”where it can actually go and activate a tool and interact with the world and perceive things. Very different technical architecture, and quite frankly, appropriately so, because it's solving a different problem. Now you fast forward into the future of an enterprise. Well, yep, still got proprietary data and still got unique skills, except now I have a path to digitize both of them, and that's the thing that's going to profoundly change most enterprises. John Roese touches on an important point about the future of AI being in the interconnectivity between tools such as AI agent integration and RAG-based chatbots. I recommend listening to the entire episode to hear more about how John Roese's team applies such integrations at Dell Technologies, based on the social media response. Listeners absolutely loved that episode.

In maybe one of the liveliest conversations I've ever had on the show, we talk about the co-authors' latest O'Reilly book on Polars and how their work with the major Dutch utility, Alliander, helped them to write *Python Polars: The Definitive Guide*. Earlier in the episode, you mentioned a real-world implementation of Polars and maybe, as you said, maybe the first ever production instance of Polars. So am I right in understanding that's Alliander? I'm probably butchering the pronunciation of that.

Yeah, Alliander is a power grid provider in the Netherlands. Also, they provide the infrastructure for both electricity and gas in a third to half of the Netherlands, I believe.

Yeah. So, the largest utility company in the Netherlands. Therefore, I can't even say Netherlands. That's how bad I am at Dutch pronunciation. Um, Netherlands. That's actually easier. Is it that way, isn't it?

Um, for us it is.

Oh, that's what you're talking about. I was wondering what is this country? Where are these Netherlands? That ain't no country I ever heard of. And uh, yeah, so tell us about that project and what it was like. Actually, it'd be interesting to know if, like, when was there overlap in working on the book and working on that project, and did working on a Polars book help with a real-world implementation? Anyway, that's kind of an interesting side question.

Yeah. Yeah. So, the origin story here is that Thijs and I, we were both very excited about Polars. We were writing a book about it, and then all of a sudden, weâ€”umâ€”it became clear that at Alliander, we needed to speed up the pipeline; right? We need to lower cost; we needed to process much more data, and in the current state, that just wasn't possible. It was a combination of not only Python and pandas but also our code, so it was very inefficient. To give you an idea, we were running this on a single AWS instance that had over 700,000 gigs of RAMâ€”700 gigs of RAM. And so, um, yeah, we can provide you a link with more backstory to this with some actual numbers, but we were very excited and we were like, "Hey, let's try this out. Let's do this." At first, the team was very hesitant, right? We're thereâ€”two people, or three actually, we had another colleagueâ€”three people promoting Polars that is being developed at Xomnia, right? So they were very skeptical, understandably. So what we did in order to convince them is to just take on a very small piece of code, right? Some low-hanging fruit and benchmark it and reimplement the pandas code into Polars and then just show the numbers. And by then they were immediately convinced, all right, this is indeed way faster, uses way less memory. Let's try this out. Let's take on this huge codebase piece by piece by translatingâ€”not one-to-one, because you can't do that. You really have to reason about the inputs and the outputs and then do it in an idiomatic way; right? You cannot just translate pandas to Polars. Um, and you know, I think it took usâ€”well, six months, a year, I don't even rememberâ€”but eventually, I left that client at that time, but there was a moment like, "Okay, we can now get rid of R and pandas as a dependency of this project," and it's been running smooth ever since.

Yeah, definitely. Yeah, I think ultimately like the size of jobs at the beginning was about 500 gigabytes for just that task of doing like one calculation, and we shrunk it downâ€”like both being a consequence of implementing Polars but also as we were going, rehashing some of the code structure that we were using in the project. We hashed it all the way down from 500 to 40 GB, which makes it a lot moreâ€”a lot more doableâ€”calculations.

And so the second part to your question was like, okay, how does thisâ€”how did this influence each other, the book writing and putting it into production? And this wasâ€”yeah, it was a perfect match because when you're justâ€”when you're actually need to put it into production, when you have a real problem to solve, that's also when you start to notice the limits, right? Or maybeâ€¦


Inconsistencies or missing functionality. For example, um, it there was this um, random sampling with weights, right? That's something that you can do in pandas. You just give it another column that indicates the weights uh, for the sampling. That's something maybe even up until this point, something that Polaris doesn't have. Luckily, that was for an ad hoc analysis that we had to do. But at that point, you know, it it becomes clear uh, what Polars can and cannot do. Also, when you write, you you start to look at things from a a little bit of a higher level. So sometimes we noticed inconsistencies in naming or missing methods like, hey, why is there no um, inline operator for the core operation, right? That's something that nobody ever thinks about, but when you when you need to put in a table in your book and you need to fill in, you know, all the all the pieces, that's when you start noticing these kind of things. So, you know, we were able to um, also, you know, submit some issues, maybe even a few uh, pull requests to Polars itself along the way.

From writing nonfiction, I turned to CEEK, a new platform for education with VR capabilities. In Episode 889, I talked to CEEK's founder, Mary Spio, about the potential for CEEK to revitalize the way we learn and make even specialist education accessible worldwide. Another thing that's really cool about CEEK is how it could potentiallyâ€”I mean, platforms like CEEK or VR in generalâ€”how it could help with education. So in the US, for example, there's a shortage of 400,000 uh, you know, kindergarten to grade 12 teachers. So primary and secondary school teachers and post-secondary institutions, there will also be shortages coming because those workforces are unusually old. And so college and university faculty are going to be retiring. And so education is failing to attract and retain faculty and has equity failings that cascade into long-term disadvantages for students. Um, and you've described previously how one professor can teach 100,000 students via CEEK. So where do you see uh, VR CEEK potentially having a long-term impact on improving educational outcomes? Right. Where we see it is in in multiple ways, right? Because right now, like you said, the the shortageâ€”I saw a stat somewhere that was like, you know, Europe needs this much. Uh, US, North America needs this much. It was like 4.6 million total. And then it says Africa needs a miracle because it's like when you look at the rest of the world um, the shortage is so dire and so a platform like CEEK, we allow a single individual to be able to teach, you know, at scale so they can present their course um, you know, virtually and then people are also able to experience it.

The reason why we're getting interest from the likes of EVEL of the world is because this is a brand new industry, right? So, for example, you have the mass displacement of a lot of the current jobs as we know it and they also have to train people for all these new autonomous vehicles, new um, you know, all these new uh, industries that are coming out as a result of automation and you need, for example, 100,000 um, EVEL pilots within the next few years, which means you have to train a million. You cannot put a million people in these very expensive aircraft; it's also very dangerous. You know, it's uh, it's a danger to the person; it's a risk to the aircraft. But on CEEK, you can have a million people training at the same time with the virtual reality headsets and they're able so that person is able to really scale themselves and have all these people train around the world. Um, and that's basically what we're building today. And this isn't just a sample scenario. We are working with the leading um, you know, electric aircraft company. Um, and and and they're exploding, right? They have a massive backlog because right now when you look at uh, fuel-based um, airplanes, right? helicopters that are being used for logistics and uh, delivery and stuff like that. It's that cost about 4,000 an hour in fuel. It's costing about 300 an hour. So even beyond being good for the environment, it's also good for business, which is why they have these massive backlogs and they have this need to train people at scale. And these are things that you just can't do physically, which is why you know our platform is now in demand.

And then the other aspect is the fact that in VR, the brain hasn't developed the ability to differentiate between um, what you do in VR. For the first time, we're creating memories, right? So it's almost as if you're actually flying the aircraft. It's almost as if you actually, you know, um, moving the um, equipment and doing all these things. So, you're building memory, which means you're building experience. So, you can now show up day one now able to train in that helicopter because you've gotten that thousand hours or however many hours that you need before you can step inside the real deal. Um, and and the same thing applies, you know, whether it's elementary education, primary education, um, for the CPR, we built CPR for the children's hospital for adult, infant, and child um, CPR. The interesting thing is this was for new mothers because actually before I did the CPR program, I didn't even know there was a difference between infant, child, and adult CPR. And a lot of new moms don't either, you know. Um, and so by them putting on the headsets, they were able to learn and train and they felt more confident than watching a video because they were actually holding the baby and they were, you know, doing um, all the different actions. Um, and the um, you know, the clinicians and the EMT that we worked with also felt better equipped. Um, the reason Baptist Health was looking at the nursing residency is because there's such a huge gap between nurses uh, the average age of a nurse today is 50 years old. That's how big the gap is because a lot of people are staying a year or two and then they're leaving. And the reason there's such a high uh, turnover is not because of competence but rather confidence. You know, a lot of people that a lot of nurses by nature are very um um very caring. So a lot of them are afraid that they don't want to hurt someone. Um, so by now being able to learn and and make the mistakes they don't want to make a mistake on a real person.


So now they can make a mistake; they can practice; they can do all of these things in VR and feel more confident to be able to do it in real life.  And then there are other areas that you just need to do in VR versus in person, like intubation, where they're learning how to insert a tube into somebody's throat, and a lot of times they will perforate the throat. Today, what some hospitals do to train is they hire low-income people and pay them, and then they can test intubation on them. Who wants to perforate their organs for $50? I mean, not me. I don't want to do that.  Yeah. And unfortunately, you have the homeless, the elderly. Some people also do the testing on the elderly with Alzheimer's to train the nurses how to do the intubation.

Yeah. Oh my goodness, that's shocking.

Yeah. VR definitely seems like a more humane way to be learning that.

Oh my goodness. Yeah. And you can do that without the risk of perforating anybody's organs.  Yeah. Being able to make mistakes and learn from them is such a core part of education. Learning from past mistakes is also an unavoidable part of running a business.

My last clip is from Episode 891 where I speak to Martin Brunthaler about the lessons he learned as the Co-founder and Chief Technology Officer of Adverity. We have listeners at home. A lot of our listeners are either hands-on data science practitioners, like machine learning engineers, AI engineers, data scientists themselves, or people who are interested in building products or companies that leverage generative AI. What are the kinds of lessons that you've learned in implementing a product like data conversations at Adverity? Like what do you need to do? What are all the things you need to line up in advance of bringing in a large language model and having conversations work effectively with data? You know, you talked a moment ago about the issues that you typically see without this kind of conversation in place where people have a dashboard and it's not exactly the information you needed; it's too fixed in its outputs, and so then people end up going and digging under the covers into the raw source data to try to really find answers, which adds strain onto the data analyst team. So I get all of the advantages of being able to have a conversation with your data, but what are the things that youâ€”that are listeners, if they want to be making this similar kind of transitionâ€”what do they need to get right in order for that conversational aspect to work out?

So I think one really critical piece is the quality of the data underneath.  So each sourceâ€”and there are many aspects of data qualityâ€”if you will. Also, from an academic perspective, you can list those out, but from a more practical perspective, you need a complete data set that is also very well aligned with all the various sources that you have. So data harmonization plays a role in this as well.  And we built out a data quality component in our platform that helps you monitor all those issues that you can have in your data. There are specific monitors for data quality in marketing. There's a concept called naming conventions, for example, for campaign names that we can monitor and act on in an intelligent manner. But there are also simple things like if you onboard a generic source from a database or from a REST API, you want all the data types to be aligned. Data formats need to be aligned. You want all your data to be harmonized in UTC, for example. You need to clean up some stuff. This is also why there are some transformations going on, usually either by splitting up, combining various sources, and all those things. But I think it's very critical to get the quality right. You need to be alerted if something's going wrong. You want to preventâ€”not saying dirty, butâ€”problematic data sets from hitting your production environment. And I think we can help in this discipline quite a bit. You can help in the discipline by having these kinds of data quality reportings built into the platform.

Yeah. But also the multi-layer approach to this. So we keepâ€”we keepâ€”we keep always a raw data set that can then be used as a starting point to reiterate on transformations, for example. So you can always go back to the previous state and improve your transformations. There's also, obviously, today an AI system helping you to compose those transformations. But if youâ€”and this is specifically always very useful for those types of generic sourcesâ€”but you canâ€”you know, it's kind of a simplified data wrangling exercise, if you will. And then once you're satisfied with that, there's a component that helps you monitor the quality as it flows through the system. There's anomaly detection and all the things that you want to monitor on.

Right. Right. Right. Yeah. So built-in anomaly detection would be key to this working out. How about when you think about theâ€”there's a huge amount of breadth of capabilities that you could potentially get from a conversational interface when you're designing a conversational product. How do you figure out, okay, this is the range of things that we're going to support or not support, and then how do you select the right large language model for that breadth of features that you decide to support?

Um, yeah, let's start there. I have more kind of follow-on questions from that, but I feel like that's a good starting point.

Yeah, I think it's useful. And maybe one thing to add to the previous question, in terms of quality, like I already said, the data dictionary descriptions, understanding of lineage is very critical as well. So, and this goes also into the design of our conversations interface and how people can interact with that. We iterate very quickly. So we haveâ€”you knowâ€”we're going through a pretty fast-paced development cycle with this, adding features like every week, and we have a dedicated team taking care of benchmarking and analyzing the quality of responses. So we're using frameworks to monitor that and the data scienceâ€¦


Team, and uh, is having a continuous test on, you know, we have a kind of a predefined set of uh responses that we expect from our questions, and we can monitor on those and improve and test models as we go.  And to be fair, the plan is also, at the moment, we committed to one model, but um there's also the plan to use different models for different aspects of of an um of our capability. So, for example, we could use a different model to compile our SQL query, a different model to do like the pre-flight qualification of a question. Um, a different model to do the actual conversation. Um, so yeah, that that's also possible. Nice. Nice.

So, I imagine something like, you know, obviously, uh, the questions that I ask you are kind of tricky because I'm trying to get at like, you know, what are the things that people need to be doing in order to, you know, build these kinds of conversational interfaces like you did, but obviously there's proprietary things involved that youâ€¦

Yeah. Yeah. It's it's I think there's there's no trade secret in in building, if you will, a lot of uh um LLMs and uh and the type of APIs they offer are similar in in regards to their capabilities, and you see like all models kind of reaching the same capability and you know basically the leaderboards change just you know every every you know other month you'd have another leader, but everyone's catching to the same state of quality, if you will. I think where it then uh boils down to is how you put the components together to create an a compelling and exciting use case on top of that. And um I think in terms of how this works from a from a technical perspective, um it's pretty straightforward. You can qualify a user input into a type of question. Select the model that you want to run with. Um, basically feed it with a system prompt and additional information about the model, which is very critical to get the answer right. Um, I use this to create a SQL query, verify it's actually a valid query that that can be executed, fire the query, um, use the data to run some pre um, some you know basic analysis and create a decent nice answer for the user. And for us the use case then circles a lot around the table that we generate from that kind of uh response because what what what our approach to this is is first of all in terms of democratization we're targeting uh two sides of the business, one of which is IT and the other one is uh is in like the business user, and both um have a requirement to um access data.

Um, so rather than going through a full chain of various teams, you know, so it used to be that you had to create a ticket to get access to data; the data set would then be prepared within two weeks and put onto I don't know a Snowflake table or whatever; today a Snowflake table; it used to be something entirely different um so and and with this you can actually run the query, create a a table in near real time available for your further analysis, and that's kind of exciting for us.
